ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live class lecture on zoom
The course was taught via zoom sessions with slides and syllabus outlines.
No

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of Ancient Mesopotamia, the origins of civilization, how empires in the near east have risen and fallen, and much much more.
I learned about where ancient civilization came from in a deeper way than I have ever before. It was a very thorough class about ancient civilization and how it developed up until today.

I have learned a lot about the history of the development of human kind in the middle east and about the early history of the region. I have also learned a great deal about the background for the current political climate. I have also learned a great deal about the ins and outs of archeology which was extremely interesting and new to me.
Knowledge of how climate affects ancient civilizations. Applying the scientific method to a humanities course.
I learned about the progression of civilization in the Near East, with a special focus on the climactic impact on civilization and the evidence of ancient climate change.

We not only learned about the history of ancient Mesopotamia (and some modern history towards the end of the course), but we also explored the way in which new archaeological techniques are revealing more about some of the motivations of large-scale historical events. The material of this class combined multiple fields; it mixed archaeology, environmental studies, history, and some anthropology into a very cool and unique learning experience.
making connections throughout history and locating significance
I gained more insights into the role of climate in shaping human history, as well as the mechanism and nature of imperialism, ancient and modern.

I developed my my reading comprehension and analytic skills. I learned a lot about how the development of civilization. Specifically the climactic reasons different areas developed quicker than others.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest strength is professor Harvey Weiss. His passion for the subject makes every lecture extremely engaging. Because he knows the subject so well, is able to assign relevant readings and movies that don't even feel like homework. The structure of only a midterm and a final also allows the student to not have to worry about other assignments, and simply absorb the knowledge from the lectures and readings at their own pace.
I enjoyed the supplemental readings and movies. The only thing I would change is I wish we had more discussions in class.

The strengths of this class are that the material for the most part is interesting and, also, the teacher is extremely interested in the material. The class takes a very interesting approach to history viewing it a archeological lens rather than straight facts. This allows for the class to explore more theories rather than straight fact which is very interesting. The weaknesses of this class are that the class can get caught up on one point for too long which can get a little boring at times.
Professor Weiss was very interesting and passionate in lecturing. However, I wish there was more open discussion in class.
The syllabus was excellent and really aided learning. The selections of readings were excellent too.
The content of the course was very interesting, though increased opportunity for class participation would have been nice.

A big strength of this course is the material and the vast knowledge that Professor Weiss has from working in the Middle East for years. We read many articles that he had written (and even more which cited him) and got to learn about many of the sites which he excavated. My favorite parts of the course were Professor Weiss's anecdotes about his time excavating. The only critique I have is that this class was not really a seminar, but more of a small lecture. I didn't mind it, and given the material I don't know exactly how much there is to discuss, but there is a bit of an issue with false advertising.
Professor Weiss is a phenomenal teacher. it is very interesting subject and using modern movies to make connections works very well
This course is really informative and has a highly organized syllabus.
I would have preferred more discussion than lecture. The lecture was very engaging but it would have been nice to have some more engagement and discussion as well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The only practice used was zoom. I think it worked well, and the course was not hindered at all due to the circumstances of the year.
I really liked the zoom format. It was a small class so it worked well and we got a lot of engagement from the professor.

The systems which worked for this class toward learning during Covid were the small seminar style class which allowed the entire class to talk and pay attention. Also, the exam format worked well as it was straightforward and easy to understand how to study for. I also appreciated that the lectures were all posted online which made it easy to follow along during the zoom class.
I appreciate the lecture format for virtual learning. The slides were interesting and there were plenty of photographs on canvas to look at.
Zoom classes worked very well, as slides were screenshared, and all students had access to the syllabus with lesson outlines.

Generally, I think everything was a success. All of our lectures were basically just Powerpoint lectures via Zoom, and I imagine that they were not too different from how they would have been in person. Sometimes towards the end of the class it would seem to drag on a bit, but I think that's just a symptom of online learning in general, not of this class.
All is good
The zoom classes were engaging. There were some technical difficulties, but otherwise it went very smoothly and was very engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to any student who is interested in learning history from a passionate teacher. Every lecture was engaging, the concepts discussed were exciting and still hold relevance to todays world. This is the best first year seminar offered, taught by one of Yale's best Professors. Not to mention, the subjects discussed in this course came from the research of the actual professor.

Yes I would. I thought it was really interesting and delved into a topic that I think many of us know on the surface but don't know much below that. The professor really knows about what he is talking about because he has worked in the area his entire career.

Yes I would but on the condition that the student does not mind reading as there is a good amount of reading for most homework assignments. If they are ok with the reading than the class is very interesting and the material is for the most part understandable and straightforward.
Yes
Yes, because it is a good blend of science and humanities with many interesting readings.
I would recommend the course to another student because the subject matter is very interesting and the professor provided a lot of great insight into a variety of topics.

I would, but it would have to be someone with interest in the subject area. We read a lot of academic papers, and the material was pretty specialized, so I imagine that not everyone would be interested in the course. However, for students who like history, are interested in archaeology, or want to learn more about how society came to be, I would highly recommend this course.
yes
Yes! Prof. Weiss has a unique perspective on historic events in ancient Mesopotamia.

I would, it was very enjoyable and the material was very very interesting. It was a relatively easy workload which fit right along my other classes as something easier that I could enjoy without stress.
